Tom Clancy’s Ghost Recon Wildlands is an open-world tactical shooter built around cooperative play, infiltration, and large-scale mission freedom. Set in a fictionalized Bolivia dominated by a powerful cartel, the game presents a sprawling landscape of mountains, jungle, deserts, and rural settlements. Its design emphasizes player-driven approaches, allowing stealth, direct assaults, or mixed tactics depending on preference.

The narrative follows a four-person Ghost team tasked with dismantling the Santa Blanca cartel by targeting key lieutenants and destabilizing its operations. Story progression is segmented into regional arcs, each focused on a specific cartel figure with their own personality, influence, and mission chain. While the overarching plot remains straightforward, the structure provides consistent goals and context for each zone.

Gameplay centers on coordinated tactics. Players can mark targets, sync-shot enemies, deploy drones, breach compounds, and plan multi-angle attacks. The AI teammates function reliably, enabling solo players to execute synchronized eliminations. In co-op, coordination becomes more dynamic, turning infiltration and extraction into fluid team operations. The variety of weapons, attachments, and gadgets supports experimentation.

The open world is one of the game’s strongest elements. Each province offers different terrain, enemy density, and environmental obstacles, encouraging players to adjust strategies. Helicopters, motorbikes, trucks, and boats provide rapid traversal across wide distances. Side activities such as resource raids, convoy interceptions, and rebel support missions contribute to progression while keeping the environment active.

Enemy encounters combine patrols, fortified bases, and cartel-controlled towns. Outposts are designed with multiple entry points, vantage positions, and varied security levels, enabling stealth paths or high-intensity assaults. The presence of Unidad—the hostile military force—adds an extra layer of tension, as their involvement escalates difficulty quickly.

Presentation highlights the environmental scale. Day-night cycles, weather changes, and distant vistas reinforce the sense of a living landscape. Audio design supports tension with distinct gunfire, radio chatter, and situational music. While character animations and dialogue can feel utilitarian, the world itself remains visually cohesive and functional for tactical play.

Tom Clancy’s Ghost Recon Wildlands succeeds as a cooperative, open-ended tactical shooter that gives players broad control over how missions unfold. Its strengths lie in world scale, flexible combat systems, and replayable infiltration scenarios. For players seeking a large, mission-driven sandbox focused on teamwork and planning, it provides a comprehensive and adaptable experience.

Tom Clancy’s Ghost Recon: Wildlands is… fine, but it trips over its own ambitions more often than not. I enjoyed clearing territories and watching the map open up, but the experience becomes painfully repetitive, same missions, same enemies, same side-quests, same grind. It all starts to feel copy-pasted after a while.

Tier mode doesn’t help. If you want to progress, you’re forced to play on Extreme difficulty, which basically turns every enemy into an instant aimbot. They either rush you and melt you in two seconds, or they glitch out and stand still. About 90% of the difficulty comes from fighting the game’s buggy AI and janky mechanics, not actual challenge.

Basic gameplay logistics are equally frustrating. Fail a mission and you might respawn 3km away thanks to the broken checkpoint system. Call in a vehicle? The game happily spawns it 2km away on the nearest road, which is almost never where you need it. And the vehicle selection itself is bizarrely limited, your default options are a sedan, an MRAP, or a dingy little helicopter. If you want anything more interesting, even after grinding the entire game to completion, you have to go hunt it down manually.

Rescue missions are the worst offenders, you’re expected to pull some clueless NPC out of a building stuffed with aimbot enemies, and the mission can fail just because the person you’re rescuing decides to bug out and get stuck inside.

To top it off, I had to mute in-game voices for the last 30 hours thanks to a bug that made my AI teammate repeat the same cringey line nonstop.

Overall, Wildlands is “just okay.” A huge open world with surprisingly little to do besides grind, bogged down by repetitive content, technical issues, and inconsistent AI. I finished it, but with minimal enjoyment.

5/10 - Play if you have nothing else to do or play

I'm torn about this game. It definitely is good overall, but I have rarely ever had a single player game be so rage inducing. Why? Because of the ai controlled teammates.
Let's split the game into positive and negative aspects.

First the negative, because I just had to rage quit before getting a stomach ulcer.
- The ai controlled teammates are HORRENDOUS in the sense of actual gameplay. Even if they try to be useful, they really aren't. I catch them standing around in the middle of a fight, while looking completely lost and just getting blasted by bullets. But that isn't the worst part. The worst part is their unparalleled ability to be three miles away, while you are in the enemy base fighting for your life. I don't know, if they are taking a sh*t in a bush or having a smoke, but they are so far away, they aren't even on the minimap. If I then go down against two dozen enemies in an Unidad camp, they finally run in to do their only actual job (being a one or two time medkit), but even then they manage to screw up and die on the way or get stuck or something else. And in a stealth mission? Yeah... Forget it. I had to redo missions so many times, because I have to play as a one man army with three brain cells tagging along and making my life hell.
- Then there is the problem with the start-up time, which is enormous (even if the Ubisoft thing is already running, it doesn't matter wait time stays the same). I can easily start the game and then have breakfast, before it finally fully starts (probably 15 to 20 minutes). People should plan for a long wait. At least it will be stable, once it finally managed to get going.
- The controls feel pretty clunky at times, due to the age of the game. Things like Nomad having a seizure behind cover or facing the wrong way and straight up refusing to simply turn around are a regular occurence. Such things. Sometimes you just have to fight the bad guys and the controls at the same time.
- My final grief is the climbing mechanic... I'm pretty sick and tired of being told where I can climb or not. If there is a spot a primary school kid could climb, but a Special Forces Operator can't do it, because the game says "No"... then I feel (rightfully) annoyed.

Now the positives. And don't get me wrong, there are a lot of those, too. I'm just so fed up with the ai... >_>
- There is a lot to do with all the main missions, side mission, collectibles and what not.
- The overarching story is good and every bad guy (or every señora mala ;P) has their own story. They are fleshed out characters with their own background and personality. Some are even likable to a degree or you feel bad for one or two of them.
- The environment looks nice and diverse. It is rare to notice buildings repeating due to being used too often. Villages/towns, camps and other places feel unique.
- The game gives lots of opportunities for customization. You can "dress up" both the main character and the other three brain cells (aka the teammates). Most of the weapons are also very customizable in both function and appearance. It is easy to choose a personal playstyle and then do it fashionably.

All in all it is an entertaining game, if you can look past the frustrations and don't mind being sabotaged by your teammates. I shut down the game in frustration again and again, but I also try again (and again) the next day, because I want to know the rest of the story.
Personally I bought it on a huge sale (80% discount) and it definitely is worth the money I paid. But I'm not sure about paying the full price, though. I would recommend waiting for a sale and I also advocate for playing Wildlands before Breakpoint, due to the improvements to the mechanics in Breakpoint, which makes Wildlands feel clunky (as I mentioned before). And obviously because Breakpoint kinda sorta continues the story and is set after Wildlands. (I started Breakpoint first, because it was on sale first XD Now I regret it a little, due to the frustration I feel regarding the older controls.)
And if you are easily enraged by having to babysit three imbeciles... then maybe this isn't for you. Spare yourself the stomach ulcers. ;D

I quite enjoyed this game, especially more so with friends. Combat in this game is good and satisfying. Enemies are not bullet sponges you can easily kill them with 3-4 bullets. But same rules apply to you, you are no bullet sponge either at close range you die fairly quickly like a effing NPC. Playing solo in higher difficulty zones becomes a real challenge since there's no one to cover you or correct your mistake or revive you if you die (though you can always use AI teammates). But I don't think I am alone in this when I say that the slowed bullet velocity and bullet drop in this game is exaggerated from what I know it is intentional. Recoil also feels to much sometimes since most of the strong guns have high recoil.  Mission variety is good you won't get bored and it's not repetitive. The bosses in this game have interesting stories. The world has a variety of biomes from deserts and forests to snowy mountains, swamps and sometimes underground bases. Though for me the map is slightly too big and travelling from one point to the other gets a bit boring (but not if you put the first person mod). The weapon customisation is satisfying you can put like 6 attachments each having more than 5 options to choose from. There are plenty of weapons to choose from like 30-40+. But some weapons are locked behind weapon crates which either needs to be bought or you need to get to level 30 to buy the crates with in-game currency. Player customisation is also good though quite a few items are again locked behind crates (you know Ubisoft with their micro-transactions). And I don't know why they made female operator faces so ugly there are only 2 which look OK, it's such bummer. But if you play as a man then don't worry all of them look like chads. Now the stealth in this game is not forgiving. Not because it is challenging but frustrating. You miss one shot with your sniper and the enemy runs like a mofo and it is almost impossible to shoot him again to stop him from alerting others since the bullet velocity is so slow that you have to aim a few centimetres forward predicting its path but that's not enough he immediately finds cover calls all of his homies and somehow they know my exact location even when I shot half a kilometre away from the base with a suppressor on. So being stealthy is really hard in this game. But yes, taking one enemy out while your buddy takes the other feels so damn satisfying and if you do everything right the stealth feels very rewarding.

One huge flaw in this game is the stuttering you get even after running the game at 60 fps and lowering most settings. One fix that works for most people is to download nvidia profile inspector and turn on frame limiter to 60, turn on vsyn and tripple buffering and vertical sync tear control to adaptive. Worked wonders for me. SSD is a must since the loading times are super long. And one more thing that gets annoying is that when you call for a vehicle, especially a heli they spawn like half a mile away.

My suggestions:
After you get a hold of this game try playing it without the HUD, maybe just keep the map for navigation but after disabling the enemy location feature.
If you start to get bored try out the First Person View Mod. It is in my opinion a must. It adds an extra thick layer of immersion and realism and the world feels truly vast and believable. The installation of this mod is so easy even a 4 year old can do it. But your friend also needs to put the same mod if you want to play together. And don't worry you won't get banned.
And personally the standard edition is enough you don't need to buy the ultimate unless you want the DLC which I have seen has mixed reviews.

All in all I'll give this game 7/10 and 8/10 with the FPS mod. If only the stealth was more realistic and the game was more optimised it can get more points.

A stealth game needs to be completely predictable, so that if you get caught, you can only blame yourself.
It is not good stealth when an enemy can spot you crouching in the foliage in the dark, while wearing invisibility cloaking. It is not good stealth when I can't reliably take down an enemy with a melee attack, or when bodies are detectable, but you cannot move them.
The biggest example of this lack of polish is the Sam Fisher DLC mission, where you cannot kill anyone, nor get spotted, and whenever I would talk to him and get stuck in a cutscene, a guard, who did not see nor hear me, would walk up the stairs, notice me, and then that would fail the mission.
Worst of all, I managed to distract him once with a flare, and after you talk with Sam, you have to then kill everyone. What was the point of not killing them, exactly?

The UI is fine, apart from the detection/damage indicator. Games 20 years before this game already figured this out. If the damage indicator points a nice horizontal right, you would assume that you are getting shot from 3 o'clock, right? No, you're actually being shot from somewhere between 12 and 1, and the moment you pass 1 with your crosshair, it switches back to a completely horizontal left, disorienting you until you get used to it.

The vehicles are janky, but this is incredibly fun when playing with friends.
Mortars are useless unless it's for destroying stuff like jammers. We would often joke that "The game could really use a mortar upgrade that allows you to kill enemies".

Another big issue with stealth is that they tried to recreate the Far Cry random event generator, like when you're clearing out outposts and a random tiger shows up for extra chaos. This worked great in Far Cry. Not at all here. You're doing a stealth mission, in a game with janky stealth mechanics, and what little predictability enemy behavior has is ruined by the fact that the rebels, or the other enemy force showed up (especially annoying with Unidad helicopters, forcing you to either get detected or shoot them down and get detected from that) and started shooting at the guys you are trying to sneak around.

Now, I'm not saying that the game sucks cause it can't compare to stuff like MGSV, or Thief or something, but Ubisoft is well-known for making plenty of stealth classics that are either up there with the champions, or serving as the pillars they stand on, so this was massively disappointing.

If it was just a bad game that'd be it, but the fact that this game has so much potential and care put into it makes the lack of polish sting so much more.

One of the most compelling aspects of Wildlands is the ability to tailor the difficulty to your preference, so use it. The game features multiple difficulty levels, each of which significantly alters how players approach missions:

Arcade Mode: Ideal for casual players, this mode allows for more forgiving enemy AI and plenty of room for error. It’s great for those who just want to enjoy the game’s story and explore the world without constant tension.

Regular Mode: A balanced experience that still allows for tactical play but with a safety net. Enemies pose a moderate challenge, and resources are plentiful.

Advanced Mode: Requires more strategic thinking. Enemies are more aggressive, reinforcements arrive quicker, and stealth becomes much more important.

Extreme Mode: The ultimate test for tactical players. One wrong move can cost you the entire mission. Enemy AI is relentless, spotting you quicker, coordinating attacks, and responding with deadly precision.

Limited Resources: You can only carry one primary weapon at a time, making loadout choices critical.
Realistic Reloading: Partial reloads discard any remaining bullets in a magazine, requiring proper ammo management.
No HUD or Minimal Assistance: The absence of traditional game aids increases immersion, requiring players to rely on natural navigation and observation.
Teamwork is Everything: Whether playing solo with AI teammates or in co-op, every action must be coordinated to avoid detection and minimize risks.
